HERALD EXAMINER Los Angeles, California July 19, 1963
State Drafts Anti-Smoking Plan
Health Dept. Seeks Curbs on Sales, Use
The State of California literally declared war on sigarette-smoking today on the basis of a Department of Public Health report which labelled the habit "a severe hazard to health" and recommended its com- piete abandonment.
""It is estimated that if the In order to reduce smoking trend is not interrupted In California, the report pro within another 60 years more posed a four point program in- than 100.000 California chil. cluding the following pro- dren now of school age will visions: die of lung cancer before reaching 70.
1. More intensive edaca tion of profession - in L've bealth and educational fields.
2. Stricter enforcement of the law prohibiting the stir of cigarettes to minors.
3. Removal . f cigate'":" vending machines fraca public health and other health facilities.
4. Establishment of dem- enstration anti-smokin: clinics.
RESTRICTIONS
The report. released in as to recommend a ban on. Berkeley by Dr. Lester Brew cigarette ad"er ting but it Jow, chief of the division of did say that The department preventive medical services. advocates "more careful work" Laid that the restrictions which with advertising agencies and would prohibit smoking in other public info: nation public places might help to curb the habit generally. It workers. went on to say:
"The Server of the "Don't Spil' campaign in the hy. glene of a half-century ago might be re inveked against cigarette smoking."
6-PAGE REPORT
Based on studies mane over the past 15 years, the 56 page report noted that during the last 60 years. lung cancer has energed from bring a rare disease to one that weused 1:30 deaths in Califen ta in 1961."
Mortality from coronary heart disease was about twice as high among cigarette smokers as compared to non smokers, the sharply critical review continued.
In addition to enforce ment of its four point pro- gram, the state health agency recommended that the Legislature raise giga rette taxes and restrict free cigarette distribution.
NO AD BAN
The report did not go so far

NEWS-CALL BULLETIN San Francisco, Calif. July 19, 1963
Industry Disputes Breslow
The Tobaren Institute, Inc. took issue today with the California Public Health Dept.'s tough new report on cigaret smoking.
George V. Allen of Wash- ington. D. C., president of the industry group, said la response In press inquiries:
"There is wide dispute among sentitsts as to the rauses of lung cancer and heart disease. The proposals hy Dr. Lester Breslow, who las heen opposed to tobacco for some years, are not justi- fiedl by current scientific knowledge.
"We believe the answers in these health questions w. il! ! we found in the scien- tfle laboratory, not through pronouncements.". :selected: :selected: :selected:

paragraphs.content: HERALD EXAMINER Los Angeles, California July 19, 1963
State Drafts Anti-Smoking Plan
Health Dept. Seeks Curbs on Sales, Use

The State of California literally declared war on sigarette-smoking today on the basis of a Department of Public Health report which labelled the habit "a severe hazard to health" and recommended its com- piete abandonment.

""It is estimated that if the In order to reduce smoking trend is not interrupted In California, the report pro within another 60 years more posed a four point program in- than 100.000 California chil. cluding the following pro- dren now of school age will visions: die of lung cancer before reaching 70.
1. More intensive edaca tion of profession - in L've bealth and educational fields.
2. Stricter enforcement of the law prohibiting the stir of cigarettes to minors.
3. Removal . f cigate'":" vending machines fraca public health and other health facilities.
4. Establishment of dem- enstration anti-smokin: clinics.
RESTRICTIONS

The report. released in as to recommend a ban on. Berkeley by Dr. Lester Brew cigarette ad"er ting but it Jow, chief of the division of did say that The department preventive medical services. advocates "more careful work" Laid that the restrictions which with advertising agencies and would prohibit smoking in other public info: nation public places might help to curb the habit generally. It workers. went on to say:
"The Server of the "Don't Spil' campaign in the hy. glene of a half-century ago might be re inveked against cigarette smoking."
6-PAGE REPORT

Based on studies mane over the past 15 years, the 56 page report noted that during the last 60 years. lung cancer has energed from bring a rare disease to one that weused 1:30 deaths in Califen ta in 1961."
Mortality from coronary heart disease was about twice as high among cigarette smokers as compared to non smokers, the sharply critical review continued.
In addition to enforce ment of its four point pro- gram, the state health agency recommended that the Legislature raise giga rette taxes and restrict free cigarette distribution.
NO AD BAN
The report did not go so far
In answer to those nt have" attacked reports connecting lung cancer with cigaretic smoking as being "unbiolog. kcal" and "not proving a cause and effect relationship." the report asked poignantly:
"What can be more "blolog. fral' than the life or death of a human being?"
NEWS-CALL BULLETIN San Francisco, Calif. July 19, 1963
Industry Disputes Breslow
The Tobaren Institute, Inc. took issue today with the California Public Health Dept.'s tough new report on cigaret smoking.
George V. Allen of Wash- ington. D. C., president of the industry group, said la response In press inquiries:

"There is wide dispute among sentitsts as to the rauses of lung cancer and heart disease. The proposals hy Dr. Lester Breslow, who las heen opposed to tobacco for some years, are not justi- fiedl by current scientific knowledge.
"We believe the answers in these health questions w. il! ! we found in the scien- tfle laboratory, not through pronouncements.".
